title-group.article-title: Psychometric Performance of a Novel Measure of Social Support Among Spanish-Speaking Immigrant Latino Gay Men

article-meta.aff: 1University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, NC, USA
2Wake Forest School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, NC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Paul A. Gilbert, University of North Carolina, Dept. of Health Behavior and Health Education, CB#7440, Gillings School of Public Health, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-7440, USA Email: paul.gilbert@unc.edu

abstract.p: Social support is protective for a variety of health outcomes, and individuals living outside their country of origin (“sojourners”) might use social support in distinctive ways. The authors performed a confirmatory factor analysis of the 18-item Index of Sojourner Social Support (ISSS) using data obtained from 190 Spanish-speaking immigrant Latino gay men and men who have sex with men (MSM) in North Carolina, a marginalized group for whom social support might be especially salient. The authors failed to replicate the original distinction between socioemotional and instrumental support; however, a reduced set of 11 ISSS items appeared to be a very good measure of a single latent factor, with high factor loadings (λ ≥ .87) and excellent internal consistency reliability (α = .97). The authors encourage further research to understand the psychometric properties of the ISSS, to further elaborate the most meaningful dimensions of social support among immigrant populations, and to establish whether associations exist between ISSS scores and health-related behaviors.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Substantial evidence shows that social support conveys a protective effect for a wide variety of health outcomes (Cassel, 1976; Lebowitz, 1975; Lindheim & Syme, 1983; Syme, 1987; Yen & Syme, 1999), and a typology of four conceptually distinct types of social support has been elaborated (Berkman & Glass, 2000; House, Landis, & Umberson, 1988). Among the four types, emotional support refers to expressions of empathy, love, and caring; instrumental support consists of the provision of necessary tangible goods or services; appraisal support is a form of constructive feedback that supports self-evaluation; and informational support encompasses advice, suggestions, and knowledge (Heaney & Israel, 2008). Although there is no consensus on the exact mechanisms by which social support operates, an increasingly popular explanation is the stress-buffering hypothesis where social support is purported to moderate the negative psychological effects of stressful life events (Cohen, Gottlieb, & Underwood, 2000; Stroebe & Stroebe, 1996). For example, emotional support may reduce the perceived severity of a stressor and instrumental support may bolster an individual’s repertoire of coping responses.

Despite decades of research, there is little agreement on the most appropriate and accurate measures of social support and dozens of instruments are available to researchers (Lakey & Cohen, 2000; Thoits, 1995). Recognizing that individuals living outside their country of origin (“sojourners”) may use social support in distinctive ways, particularly related to their being far from traditional sources of support such as families and friends, Ong and Ward developed the 18-item Index of Sojourner Social Support (ISSS) among English-speaking foreign residents of Singapore (Ong & Ward, 2005). In a principle components analysis, they found that the instrument assessed two social support domains, socioemotional and instrumental support. In a validation study, they replicated the two-factor structure with international university students in New Zealand. Social scientists have subsequently used the ISSS to measure social support in a variety of sojourner populations, including adult foreign nationals residing in Russia (McGinley, 2008), Korean women in the United States and Canada (Cha, 2010), German nationals working overseas (Spiess & Stroppa, 2010; Stroppa & Spiess, 2010), and foreign students at Irish universities (O’Reilly, Ryan, & Hickey, 2010). In each case, researchers reported high internal consistency reliability (α ≥ .89); however, none investigated the factor structure of the ISSS in their sample.

Recent growth of the Latino population, driven largely by immigration, provided a timely opportunity to test this novel measure in the United States. Although the largest numbers of Latinos continue to be found in traditional settlement states, such as California, Texas, Florida, and New York, recent demographic changes have been most pronounced in states with little or no historical Latino presence, particularly in the Southeast (Dockterman & Velasco, 2010; Ennis, Rios-Vargas, & Albert, 2011; Kochlar, Suro, & Tafoya, 2005). In North Carolina, for example, the Latino proportion increased from 1% to 8% of the state’s population over just 10 years (Census Bureau, 2011).

We recognized that within the rapidly growing Latino population, there exists a subgroup of men who have sex with men (MSM)—who may or may not self-identify as gay or bisexual—for whom social support might be especially salient. Immigrant Latino MSM are likely to face multiple social stressors due to their immigration experience, acculturation level, and racial/ethnic or sexual minority status. To-date, the limited research on social support among Latino MSM has largely been restricted to HIV-related topics. Social support is positively associated with condom use and disclosure of HIV status (Carlos et al., 2010; Zea, Reisen, Poppen, Bianchi, & Echeverry, 2005) and moderates the association between disclosure of HIV status to parents and disease status (Fekete et al., 2009). Compared to African Americans and Latinas with HIV, Latino MSM were more likely to obtain social support from friends and health care providers than family members (Wohl et al., 2010).

Given the potential utility of this new measure of social support for health research and mindful of concerns about its transferability to different populations, we sought to confirm the factor structure and describe the psychometric performance of the ISSS among a sample of immigrant Latino gay men and MSM in central North Carolina.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: Data for this analysis come from a study of HIV risk and protective factors among immigrant Latino gay men and MSM in North Carolina. The parent study was guided by a community-based participatory research (CBPR) partnership that included representatives from public health departments, AIDS service organizations, universities, the local Latino community (including immigrant gay men and MSM), and community-based organizations serving the Latino community. Because immigrant Latino gay men and MSM constitute what researchers sometimes label a “hard-to-reach” population, we used respondent-driven sampling (RDS), an extension of chain-referral methods that enables researchers to sample “hidden” populations when no sampling frame can be established (Heckathorn, 1997; Magnani, Sabin, Saidel, & Heckathorn, 2005; Ramirez-Valles, Heckathorn, Vazquez, Diaz, & Campbell, 2005). Recruitment began with 17 “seeds” identified by the CBPR partnership to represent the diversity of the Latino MSM community (e.g., country of origin, level of “outness” about their sexual orientation, and HIV status). Men were eligible to participate if they self-identified as Latino or Hispanic, were age 18 or older, reported sex with another man since age 18, and provided informed consent. The seeds completed the behavioral assessment, received instruction on the study’s recruitment protocol and eligibility criteria, and recruited up to three additional immigrant Latino MSM from their social networks. We compensated respondents for completing their own behavioral assessment (US$50) and for each referral who also completed an assessment (US$20)—a dual incentive process that is a hallmark of RDS.

A total of 190 men completed the behavioral assessment (Table 1). Respondents’ average age was 26 years (range 18-48), and average length of residence in North Carolina was 6 years (range <1-23 years). Most men were originally from Mexico (79%), self-identified as gay (89%), and were currently employed either year-round or seasonally (96%). Approximately equivalent proportions were single or in a dating relationship (48% and 46%, respectively). Some respondents were HIV positive (13%) or self-identified as male-to-female transgender (16%). Of 181 respondents reporting income, 83% earned less than US$30,000 per year.

tr.td: Length of time in the United States, years (n = 162)
Length of time in North Carolina, years (n = 179)

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: The ISSS was administered as part of a comprehensive assessment of HIV risk and protective factors that covered a wide range of topics, including general health status, health services utilization, substance use, sexual behaviors, household demographics, and employment characteristics, among others. The CBPR partnership developed a quantitative assessment using established Spanish-language measures whenever possible and adapting English-language measures when necessary. Following a committee approach, an increasingly preferred method (Behling & Law, 2000; Census Advisory Committees, 2004), we convened a group of individuals with complementary skills to translate the English language items, including the ISSS, into Spanish. The group included professional translators (including native Spanish speakers from Mexico and Central America), a translation reviewer, content specialists, and a questionnaire design expert. Multiple group members made independent translations of the assessment, and the full committee met to discuss and reconcile the various versions. The CBPR partnership, which included native Spanish speakers, reviewed and approved the final Spanish translation.

The ISSS presented 18 statements about tasks or behaviors relevant to social support in a foreign context, such as “comfort you whenever you feel homesick” or “tell you what can and cannot be done in [place].” Respondents reported how many people they know and are in contact with who would assist with the task or behavior using a 5-point response scale, coded 0 = no one would do this 1 = someone would do this, 2 = a few would do this, 3 = several would do this, and 4 = many would do this. All data were collected in face-to-face interviews administered by a male native Spanish speaker. We declined to use other data collection modalities, such as Audio Computer Assisted Self-Interview (ACASI), given that formative data (Rhodes et al., 2007, 2010; Vissman et al., 2009) and feedback from partnership members suggested that participants would be more likely to engage with a well-trained interviewer who could establish rapport and trust. This approach was thought to be culturally congruent given that some Latinos value personalismo, a cultural feature that stresses the importance of interpersonal relationships (Marsiglia & Kulis, 2009). Furthermore, utilizing an interviewer-administered assessment overcame both low literacy and poor vision (resulting from lack of access to optometric services). Interviews took 45 to 90 minutes to complete. Informed consent was obtained by interviewers from each respondent; the Institutional Review Board at Wake Forest University Health Sciences approved the study.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p: We used SPSS (SPSS Inc., Chicago IL) to maintain the data set and compute univariate statistics and Mplus v.6 (Muthén & Muthén, Los Angeles, CA) to conduct a confirmatory factor analysis. Since data were ordinal, we used a weighted least squares estimation algorithm. Ninety-two percent of respondents provided complete data. Missing data did not exceed 2% for any item, with four items having no missing data. Among the 15 respondents with incomplete data, there was an average of 2 missing values per person (range 1-6); these data were assumed to be missing at random. We used full information maximum likelihood (FIML) to impute missing values, ensuring use of the complete data set.

Following recommended practice, we assessed model goodness-of-fit at each iteration using several comparative and absolute measures (Kline, 2005; McDonald & Ho, 2002; Schreiber, Nora, Stage, Barlow, & King, 2006): the comparative fit index (CFI), which contrasts the specified model against a null model where there are no covariances among indicators (>.9 = good fit); the Tucker–Lewis Index (TLI), which extends the CFI by taking account of the number of parameters estimated (>.9 = good fit); the weighted root mean square residual (WRMR), which assesses the error of approximation while also taking account of the number of parameters estimated (>.05 = good fit); and the model χ2 statistic, which tests the null hypothesis that the model perfectly fits the data (χ2 = 0 indicates perfect fit).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We attempted to confirm the original ISSS structure in our sample, specifying a two-factor model in which Items 1 to 9 served as indicators of social-emotional support and Items 10 to 18 served as indicators of instrumental support. Although this model converged on a solution, results showed an unacceptably high correlation between the two latent factors (r = .968). Thus, we concluded that social-emotional and instrumental support were not sufficiently distinct latent constructs within this sample.

We respecified a single-factor model and repeated the analysis. The revised model showed good fit by two indices (CFI = .975, TLI = .972); however, there was poor fit by the χ2 statistic (χ2 = 969.381, df = 135) and weighted root mean square residual (WRMR = 2.843). In addition, 13 pairs of indicators had correlations (r ≥ .99) indicating redundant measures (Pairs 1 & 2, 4 & 5, 7 & 11, 8 & 10, 12 & 13, 12 & 16, 12 & 17, 13 & 17, 15 & 16, 15 & 17, 15 & 18, 16 & 17, 17 & 18). We deleted seven indicators involved in the unacceptably high correlations (Items 1, 4, 7, 8, 12, 15, 17) and reran the analyses.

The revised single-factor model with 11 indicators showed a similar pattern of mixed goodness of fit (CFI = .975, TLI = .968, χ2 = 512.887, df = 44, WRMR = 2.616), but standardized factor loadings were high (λ ≥ .867, Table 2), and interitem correlations were acceptable (Table 3). Internal consistency reliability for the reduced set of indicators was excellent (α = .97).

caption.p: Factor Loadings of Reduced Set of ISSS Items

tr.td: Listen and talk with you whenever you feel lonely or depressed.
Escucharlo y hablarle cada vez que se siente solo o deprimido.
Share your good and bad times.
Spend time chatting with you whenever you are bored.
Pasar tiempo conversando con usted cuando usted está aburrido.
Accompany you to do things whenever you need someone for company.
Acompañarlo a hacer cosas cada vez que necesita a alguien que lo acompañe.
Reassure you that you are loved, supported, and cared for.
Asegurarle que usted es querido, que se le da apoyo y atención.
Provide necessary information to help orient you to your new surroundings.
Darle información necesaria que lo ayuda a orientarse en su nuevo ambiente.
Help you deal with some local institutions’ official rules and regulations.
Ayudarlo a tratar con algunas de las normas y regulaciones de instituciones locales.
Explain things to make your situation clearer and easier to understand.
Explicarle cosas para que entienda su situación más clara y fácilmente.
Tell you what can and cannot be done in North Carolina.
Decirle lo que se puede y lo que no se puede hacer en Carolina del Norte.
Give you some tangible assistance in dealing with any communication or language problems that you might face.
Darle alguna ayuda concreta referente a algún problema de comunicación o de idioma que usted pudiera tener.
Tell you about available choices and options.
Decirle sobre las opciones y alternativas disponibles.

fn.p: Note: ISSS = Index of Sojourner Social Support.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We failed to replicate the two-factor structure, indicating that a distinction between social-emotional and instrumental support is not supported by our data. However, the high factor loadings suggest that the ISSS is a very good measure of some latent construct, which we suggest to be general social support based on the characteristics of the indicators. A single-factor model of social support showed acceptable goodness of fit but had redundant indicators. By excluding 7 items we arrived at a reduced set of 11 items that showed good psychometric performance.

By focusing on sojourners as a distinct subgroup and identifying the types of social support most salient to them, the ISSS represents a methodological innovation. It may be a welcome addition to researchers’ repertoire. Better operationalization of social support promises to improve our understanding of how social factors affect health outcomes. However, uncritical acceptance of a new instrument is hazardous. The ISSS has been used in several populations different from the one in which it was developed, both in the original English and in translated versions. To our knowledge, there have been no investigations of its psychometric performance beyond reporting internal consistency reliability. Thus, our study is the first to assess the ISSS factor structure in a different population from the one in which it was developed.

Several plausible explanations for our findings should be considered. Because the ISSS was developed in English, the failure to replicate its original factor structure in our sample might be due to translation problems, despite the care we took to ensure conceptual equivalence of items. A gender effect is also possible. Some socio-emotional items might not be interpreted by Latinos as indicative of appropriate masculine social support (e.g., Item 9, “Reassure you that you are loved, supported, and cared for”). Accordingly, respondents might be reluctant to endorse such items. Furthermore, there might be culturally distinct conceptualizations of social support that limit transferability of this instrument. The ISSS was developed among English-speaking sojourners in Singapore, a population for whom there might be greater division between emotional and instrumental support. Among Latino immigrants, however, the two constructs may overlap. In addition, the sampling method may also have affected our results. Because RDS depends on recruitment through social ties, all respondents had at least one person with whom they had a connection. In other words, all men in our sample had at least one possible source of social support, which might have inflated inter-item and inter-factor correlations.

Finally, our results should be interpreted cautiously because the sample size used here (n = 190) was less than the generally accepted minimum for factor analysis. Thus, our observed factor structure and parameter estimates may be less stable than that obtained in larger samples. We encourage future research on the ISSS to assess convergent and discriminant validity, particularly with established multidimensional measures of social support such as the Personal Resource Questionnaire (Weinert, 1984, 1987) or Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (Dahlem, Zimet, & Walker, 1991; Zimet, Powell, Farley, Werkman, & Berkoff, 1990).

The demands and uses of social support may indeed be distinct among adults living in foreign contexts. If so, the ISSS represents an important methodological innovation. A valid and easy-to-use instrument would be a welcome addition to the repertoire of medical, public health, and social science researchers. At present, there is no recommended measure of social support for Latinos in the United States, a large and rapidly growing minority population. We encourage future research to understand the psychometric performance of the ISSS, to further elaborate the most meaningful dimensions of social support among immigrant populations, and to establish whether associations exist between ISSS scores and health-compromising and health-promoting behaviors.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: The study was funded in part by the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (R21HD049282) and a Kenan Pre-Doctoral Fellowship (University of North Carolina).

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Paul A. Gilbert is currently a fourth-year PhD student in the Department of Health Behavior and Health Education at the University of North Carolina. He is interested in the ways that the social environment exerts an influence on behaviors, and his dissertation research will explore social stressors and coping behaviors, with particular attention to alcohol consumption, among immigrant Latino gay men and other men who have sex with men (MSM) in North Carolina. He earned a master’s degree in health and social behavior from the Harvard School of Public Health and served 5 years as a research associate at the Center for Health Improvement and Prevention Studies at the University of California, San Francisco.

Scott D. Rhodes is a public health scientist whose research focuses on the integration of community development and health promotion and disease prevention interventions in both rural and urban communities. Specifically, his research explores sexual health, HIV and sexually transmitted disease (STD) prevention, and health disparities among vulnerable communities, including substance use and obesity. He has extensive experience working with Latino communities, urban African American adolescents, persons living with HIV and AIDS, men of color, self-identified gay and bisexual men, and men who have sex with men (MSM).
